docs.lead_paragraph: Mark B. McClellan, who oversaw federal government health insurance programs for the poor and the elderly, has joined the Brookings Institution and the American Enterprise Institute. Dr. McClellan, who resigned last month as administrator of the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services, will be a senior research fellow focusing on ways to improve health care and eliminate excess costs, the groups announced on Monday. An economist and physician, Dr. McClellan's last major effort for the centers was overseeing the start of the Medicare drug benefit.

headline.main: National Briefing | Washington: New Job For Former Administrator Of Medicare Services

docs.abstract: Mark B McClellan, who resigned in September as administrator of Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services, has joined Brookings Institution and American Enterprise Institute where he will be senior fellow researching ways to improve health care and eliminate excess costs; photo (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: New Jersey’s largest health maintenance organization, which was accused of shortchanging physicians, has reached a settlement in a class-action lawsuit filed in 2002 on behalf of at least 40,000 doctors, the company and lawyers for the doctors said yesterday. Under the proposed agreement, which requires approval by a state judge, the company, Horizon Blue Cross Blue Shield of New Jersey, agreed to continue significant business practice improvements. Horizon, which insures more than 3.2 million people in New Jersey, did not admit wrongdoing, and it gave no money to the doctors, although it will pay lawyers’ fees, said Eric D. Katz, a lawyer for the doctors.

docs.lead_paragraph: Beginning next year, the government will pay parents in rural areas who have no more than one son or two daughters $75 a year each when they reach 60, the official China Daily newspaper reported. The stipend is supposed to lessen the burden on singular children who look after aged parents, many of whom in rural areas have no health insurance. China introduced a one-child policy in 1979 to control its population but later relaxed it to allow farmers in particular to have more children, especially if they have a daughter first. The policy’s main enforcement measure was fines, but, the newspaper reported, “the policy should be adapted as the nation develops.”.

docs.abstract: In this lesson, students will debate whether universities should police the behavior of their athletes outside of school, and whether college athletes should be held to a higher behavioral standard than their peers.
